Instrument.name: Cassini Oribiter Composite Infrared Spectrometer
Instrument.description: The Composite Infrared Spectrometer (CIRS) of Cassini Orbiter detected infrared light that was split into its component wavelengths to measure temperature and composition of objects. The optics assembly is comprised of a berylium Cassegrain telescope, with 50.8 cm paraboloidal primary and 7.6 cm hyperboloidal secondary, relay optics, and a pair of Michelson Polarising interferometers, covering the mid and far-IR spectral region. Both interferometers share a common scan mechanism, as does a reference interferometer which controls the sampling rate and mirror movement. The other main components of CIRS are the detectors, the electronics assembly, and the passive radiative cooler. The entire instrument is maintained at 170K, except for the mid-IR detectors which are at ~80K. The Martin-Puplett far-infrared interferometer (FIR) uses wire-grid polarisers to split, recombine and analyse the radiation. The 2-micron center to center wire spacing used in CIRS gives good response from 0-300 cm-1 and then decreasing response to 600 cm-1. The far-infrared focal plane assembly (FP1) uses two thermopile detectors to measure the final transmitted and reflected beams at the polariser-analyser. The convential Michelson mid-infrared interferometer (MIR) has a KBr beamsplitter and cube-corner retroreflectors. A germanium lens focuses the recombined beams onto the mid-IR focal plane, which covers the range 600--1400 cm-1 using two photodetector arrays.
